Nia King & Teagan Widmer: The Great Selfie Debate

By Teagan Widmer and Nia King


Podcast: The Great Selfie Debate

Nia King and Teagan Widmer on “Selfies”, Millennial Self-Representation, and the Saturated Visual Economy of Tumblr

By Teagan (Twid) Widmer and guest contributor Nia King; music courtesy of SAFE.

Nia KingÂ is a mixed-race queer art activist from Boston, Massachusetts. She currently resides in Oakland, California where she runs the podcastÂ We Want the Airwaves: QPOC Artists on the Rise.

Transcribed Selection Below:

Nia King: Thereâs been a lot of conversations recently about how our generation is allegedly super-narcissistic and how social media is making us narcissistic and I think selfies, or self-portraits, have been pointed to as the evidence of that.

My first question is, do you think that itâs accurate that our generation is perhaps more vain, and that selfies are a product of that? And secondly, do you think thatâs a bad thing?

Teagan (Twid) Widmer: I donât think weâre necessarily more vain. I think selfies are a good thing. Iâm pro-selfie. I just want to start with that.

As someone whoâs part of a marginalized group, I spent a lot of time not being able to tell my own story. Not being able to present myself the way that I wanted to present myself. Finding myself in situations where I had to let other people present me, or be represented in a way that the dominant culture saw me. I think self-portraiture allows for a way to challenge that. To say âNo, Iâm going to take control of how I look. Iâm going to put my best foot forward, what I consider to be my best foot, not what you consider to be my best foot, cause I think often those are two different things.â

Nia: Yeah, itâs very different when you take a selfie versus when somebody takes a picture of you in public and uploads it to the internet.

Twid: Yeah. I feel like selfies looks like me, and when other people take pictures of me, they donât look like me.

Nia: I can see what youâre saying about selfies give you control over how you represent yourself to the world, but how many selfies do you really need to do that? Because people donât just take one selfie, a lot of times theyâre taking and posting selfies like all the time. And even if youâre transitioning, youâre face doesnât change that much from day to the next. Soâ¦ whatâs that about? [laughing]

Twid: I work a job where I wear a uniform, and this uniform is very de-gendering for me. Itâs like a big ski-jacket type of thing, and like an orange polo, and then grey pants. None of it is really cut for women. When I first got there, they only had menâs stuff. Iâve been able to get womenâs pieces but theyâre notâ¦

Nia: Theyâre not flattering?

Twid: Theyâre not flattering. So I have to go do that 8 hours a day, 5 days a week. So when I finish a shift, in which Iâve probably been misgendered multiple times - also because Iâm usually wearing a hat where my hair is up, Iâm less likely to be gendered correctly â so sometimes that can be really mentally taxing on me. At the end of the day, when I get on BART, when Iâm back in my normal clothes, it can be really helpful for me to take a selfie, and look at myself, and say, âOh, I donât really look like a boy. Ok. Iâm ok,â you know? I feel like sometimes thatâs just really calming. And thatâs not an every day thing, but some days are worse than others, and some days I need that.

Twid: Why are you anti-selfie?

Nia: Iâm someone who mostly uses social media to promote my work as an artist. I think the reason I get frustrated is that I feel like Iâm competing with selfies and cat photos, and you just canât win.

When I interviewed Dr. Kortney Ryan Ziegler, he said something that really stuck with me. He said, âI had to take a break from social media because it was starting to hurt my feelings. Itâs easy to forget that people donât necessarily go to social media to find ground-breaking new work. They go to social media to look at cat photos.â

“I think when youâre an artistsÂ whoâs doing something like putting 8-10 hours into editing a podcast, and then you put it on tumblr and it gets like 8 notesâ¦”â¦ and then you see a cat photo or a selfie with like a gajillion, it feels like youâre just banging youâre head against the wall.

But I feel like thereâs also like aâ¦ tumblr in particular is like a visual economy, right? Itâs all about pretty photos.

Twid: Totally.

Nia: So what if youâre not cute? You know?

First of all, what if your face isnât what you want to share, or what you feel like is the thing of most value that you bring to the world? And also, what if youâre not that crazy about the way you look?

For me as a woman [and an artist], it feels really important to be valued for what I create and not what I look like.

I feel like selfies are great if you have âcute privilege,â but what if you donât? Where do you belong in the selfie economy? (20:00)
